Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Studying Hysteresis of Three-Phase Flow in Porous Media Using Dynamic X-ray Microtomography
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research will study the real-time fate and transport of three fluid phases flowing together through a rock matrix. The visualization of these fluid-flow experiments will be accomplished with fast x-ray microtomography which can produce 3D images of the position of fluids within a rock while fluids are being injected or drained from the system. The interaction between multiple fluids in porous media is important to understand because it controls many environmental processes (e.g. enhanced oil recovery, geologic CO2 sequestration, oil spill remediation in an aquifer) which affect human and environmental health. This project will be conducted at the Australian National University in Canberra, Australia in collaboration with Dr. Adrian Sheppard, a pioneer in the fast x-ray microtomography technique and a leading scientist in cutting-edge mathematical techniques for 3D image processing. Few laboratories are equipped for fast x-ray microtomography; therefore, the available instrumentation and expertise of the collaborators provide a unique opportunity to accomplish this research.

This research will utilize advances in image visualization and processing to collect unique data sets and calculate state variables relevant in modeling three-phase fluid flow systems in porous media (e.g. concurrent water, air, and oil transport in a contaminated aquifer). The project will use the Australian National University's state-of-the-art lab-based x-ray system and advanced mathematical reconstruction algorithms that utilize a priori information to collect microtomography scans in real-time. State variables of capillary pressure, fluid-fluid interfacial area, and Euler characteristic will be calculated from 3D images which have been previously unobtainable for three-phase flow systems under dynamic flow conditions. These state variables are important in two-phase flow and will be correlated to better understand the physics of three-phase flow and will also be compared with previous data sets obtained under quasi-equilibrium conditions to understand the effect of flow conditions on fluid topology and interfacial area generation.

This award, under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program, supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the Australian Academy of Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many environmentally relevant processes such as geologic CO2 sequestration and remediation of a hydrocarbon contaminated aquifer are dependent on multi-phase flow theories in porous media. Experimental methods used to validate these theories are difficult to perform due to the necessity to track multiple fluid phases and interfaces within an opaque material in real-time. X-ray computed microtomography (uCT) has been utilized to track equilibrated fluids within a rock core in a non-destructive manner. With the advent of fast-uCT, it has become feasible to perform these same experiments under transient flow conditions.

The aim of this project was to develop a fast-uCT methodology to study the transient behavior of the movement of three fluid phases (oil, water, and air) within a porous media sample. This was achieved using the lab-based uCT system and state-of-the-art reconstruction methods at the Australian National University (ANU). Transient and quasi-static flow experiments were performed in a glass bead pack (representative porous media) simulating a hydrocarbon contaminated aquifer. The attached image shows one 2D slice of this experiment within the glass bead (gray circles) sample with the three fluid phases: air (black), oil (dark gray), and water (white). To the knowledge of the researchers, these are the first 3D data sets of three-phase transient flow using a lab-based uCT system. The quality of the images is remarkable for a lab-based system and the fluid phases and their interfaces can fairly easily be separated to measure fluid saturations, fluid-fluid interfacial areas, and capillary pressures. These measures are important to better inform multi-phase flow theories that researchers and policy makers could use to develop better models to protect water resources. Due to the large amount of data collected (~4 TB), the image processing and data analysis of the data sets were not completed at the time this report was written. 

Besides the intellectual merit of this data, the project has allowed the author to be trained on the use of a lab-based uCT system. A near identical system developed by ANU was recently delivered to the author's home institution of Oregon State University (OSU). This training has allowed for interdisciplinary connections to be formed by training and sharing learned methodologies with other researchers at OSU and other institutions who seek to explore uCT in their research. Disciplines such as Material Science, Geoscience, and Civil Engineering could benefit from the ability to nondestructively visualize the interior of samples using uCT.
